'''''Strobilomyces strobilaceus''''', also called '''''Strobilomyces floccopus''''' and commonly known as '''old man of the woods''',<ref name="Bessette 2000"/> is a species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Boletaceae]]. It is native to Europe and North America. [[Basidiocarp|Fruit bodies]] are characterized by very soft dark grey to black pyramidal and overlapping scales on the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] surface.

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Strobilomyces strobilaceus'' is classified in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Strobilomyces'' of the genus ''[[Strobilomyces]]''. Species in this section are characterized by having spores that may be either smooth or with short spines or warts, ridges or reticulations. The ornamentation is reduced or absent in the suprahilar region—a depressed area near the [[wikt:hilar appendage|hilar appendage]].<ref name="Singer 1986"/>

It was first [[species description|described]] scientifically by the Italian [[natural history|naturalist]] [[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli]] in 1770 as a species of ''[[Boletus]]''.<ref name="Scopoli 1770"/>

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] are between {{convert|4|to|10|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, with a convex shape and a villous, involute margin. The cap surface is covered with dark grey to black erect scales. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is up to {{convert|14|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick.<ref name="Bon 1987"/> It is coloured like the cap and has a woolly surface and a thick, ascending [[Annulus (mycology)|annulus]]. The pores on the underside of the cap are hexagonal, coloured dirty white or grey. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thick and initially white, but will stain pink and then [[slate]] grey and black after exposure to the air. The taste of the mushroom is indistinct, with a slight earthiness. 

The dark brown to black [[spore]]s are 9–15 by 8–12 [[micrometre|μm]], short elliptic and are covered with a mesh-like ornament.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/><ref name="Pegler 1981"/>

[[File:Strobilomyces.Floccopus.001.jpg|thumb|''Strobilomyces floccopus'' tubes]]
[[File:Old man of the woods.jpg|thumb|Strobilomyces strobilaceus]]

===Similar species===
''[[Strobilomyces confusus]]'' has a slightly smaller cap with smaller and stiff scales. Its spores have irregular ridges that resemble a partial mesh. The cap of ''[[Strobilomyces dryophilus]]'' is coloured a dull grey-pink to pinkish-tan and produces spores with a complete mesh.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
''Strobilomyces strobilaceus'' is found solitary or in groups in [[Temperate deciduous forest|deciduous]] as well as [[Temperate coniferous forest|coniferous forests]] in low mountain ranges and alpine areas of Europe, North America and Asia (Iran<ref name="Asef 2013"/> and Taiwan<ref name="Yeh 1980"/>). It is less common in lowlands.<ref name="Bon 1987"/> The fungus appears between August and October and young specimens are [[edible mushroom|edible]].<ref name="Pegler 1981"/>

==Postage stamp==
On February 27, 2014, the [[Swiss Post|postal administration of Switzerland]] issued a 50-centime [[Definitive stamp|definitive]] [[postage stamp]] depicting ''Strobilomyces strobilaceus''.<ref name="urlStamps"/>
